title: Match for typewriter-type for graphic novel?
content:
Hi!  
I’m new here (though I’ve nosed around earlier).  
I’m working on a graphic novel, or actually it’s more like a ‘graphic bio’ – a biography in the form of a picture book.

In the book, there are 3-4 different kinds/lines of text – the narrator’s voice, my main character’s voice – and then excerpts from letters, song texts and poems, written for and by my main character.  
The 3 different kinds of text change a lot throughout the book, so that I sometimes will have all three kinds on one page or spread. Every page is illustrated and sometimes text is set on top of a drawing.

The two first kinds of text, the narrator and my main character, I think would work with quite many different typefaces,  
My story takes place mostly in the 1960-1980s, when my character was young – in a beatnik-/alternative surrounding. I’d like the typeface for her and the narrator’s voice to have some warmth, but without attracting too much attention to itself. Maybe slightly handwritten and/or casual.  
For now, I am leaning towards Cronos, and earlier I’ve looked at Joanna, Perpetua or Legacy Sans.

But, but, but: the letter/poem-texts are causing me a head ache! The only thing that I think really works for them, is using a “oldschool-typewriter”-face (like “Pitch”.) One with a vintage-typewriter-feel.  
But I don't think the typewriter-face doesn't mix very well with any of the above mentioned. The shapes, perhaps, but also when combined with a typewriter face, they look a little (too) formal.  
I looked at Nexus and Eureka, which both have a monotype-version, that I thought of using in stead of vintage- typewriter-type, but I think those monotypes look too contemporary for my book. Sigh.

Does this make sense? Do you have any ideas or suggestions?

I know this is the kind of thing you should discuss with a colleague, while having a coffee – but I don’t have that person right now. So – if anyone has thoughts, opinions or suggestions on this, it will be very much appreciated! Thanks so much!
author: scillas

comments.content:
\> My story takes place mostly in the 1960-1980s,  
\> ...in a beatnik-/alternative surrounding

Would a beatnik be using a typewriter? I was a young person back then and most young folks didn't use them except maybe in upper-class schools, for college term papers, and office work. And it's harder to imagine a beatnik or hippie using one. You might need to include an explanation of why they are using it.

It depends on how much “graphic” and how much “novel” the result: if the typewritten text is visually framed, it shouldn’t clash with the rest.  
If that is the case, I would go for an accurate rendition either historically (which model of typewriter?) and/or visually (a “worn out” face, like [http://www.fontfont.com/fonts/trixie](http://web.archive.org/web/20150418115001/http:/www.fontfont.com/fonts/trixie "http://www.fontfont.com/fonts/trixie")).  
If the lines (pun intended) between the different kind of text are more blurred, you could use either a classic text face with a monospaced cut (like Century) or a proportionally spaced typewriter face (like the ones suggested in the aforelinked thread or [http://www.fontsquirrel.com/fonts/lekton](http://web.archive.org/web/20150418115001/http:/www.fontsquirrel.com/fonts/lekton "http://www.fontsquirrel.com/fonts/lekton")).  
About the text faces you mention, I’m most familiar with Perpetua, and I wouldn’t recommend it, finding it a bit “frail” and maybe even pretentious.
On The Road was written on a Underwood Typewriter - Beat writers used typewriters. Dafont has many typewriter fonts - some quite good.

Thank you very much for your answers and for pointing me to the older typewriter-discussion. I'll take a closer look at Triplicate.

@ James: they did use typewriters – but also a lot of handwriting. I'm reluctant to post text and illustrations from the book, as it is not yet approved, but I can share with you a little piece of sixties typewriting: several little notes like this one, "just left - will be back later"-sort of notes, survived all these years and I feature some of them in the book. They feels like text messages from 50 years ago.  
@ riccard0: yes. The lines are blurred – and the texts not always visually separated. Century – that might work!

Thanks again.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150418115001im_/http:/typophile.com/files/type_sixities_typrewriter_5836.jpg)

\> @ James: they did use typewriters – but also a lot of handwriting.

I agree. I'm just saying it's not like today when everyone has a computer. Many folks didn't even own a typewriter. I was the editor of a newsletter in the 1970s and almost all submissions were handwritten.

I'm not saying that typewriting is a bad idea. I'm just saying that you might want to mention why a beatnik is using one.

[The Last Whole Earth Catalog](http://web.archive.org/web/20150418115001/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whole_Earth_Catalog) (1971) was assembled using photocopies and IBM Selectric type.  
What typefaces best approximate the quality of “golf ball” typography?  
I would suggest my [Brown](http://web.archive.org/web/20150418115001/http:/www.fontspring.com/fonts/shinntype/brown-gothic), for its patina of distress, although metrically it is consistent and without bounce.

@ James, they did a lot of writing in her "group". They published a magazine.  
And both her parents were writers. You mentioned social class, and when they met in the 1940, her mother, who came from a middle class family, owned a typewriter, while her father, coming from a working class background, didn't. Her's was an Erica/Erika – I know that.  
@ Nick – I like it Brown. It's has this slight vintage-tint. I like it. And nice story about WEC.  
It's hard to make the typewriter-/monospace/slab work with a serif, so I think it must be a sans. Brown could mix nicely, I think. If anything, perhaps I could use something a little more ...casual, perhaps. But it is a good suggestion.

Sounds good.

Incidentally I've got a bunch of old ones that belonged to my dad, who did some writing. Nothing fancy, this is an old Royal still in it's carrying case.
